sequence.notes: Conjugate addition of 3-methylbut-2-enylmagnesium chloride (mediated by copper) to cyclopent-2-en-1-one, with silyl enol ether formation and subsequent hydrolysis to the ketone product.

A Knoevenagel-type condensation of a cyclopentanone with dimethyl malonate, mediated by TiCl4 and pyridine, to form an exocyclic α,β-unsaturated diester. The stereocenter adjacent to the ketone is retained.
Allylcuprate (generated in situ from MeLi, CuI, and tetraallylstannane) undergoes 1,4-conjugate addition to the α,β-unsaturated diester, forming a cyclopentane with two new chiral centers.
Intramolecular cyclization and decarboxylation of a diester-substituted cyclopentane to form a bicyclo[3.2.1]octane derivative.
Conversion of a methyl ester to a Weinreb amide using N,O-dimethylhydroxylamine and trimethylaluminum.
Methylmagnesium bromide (MeMgBr) reacts with the N-methoxy-N-methyl amide (Weinreb amide) to form a methyl ketone.
Oxidation of two terminal alkenes to methyl ketones using Wacker conditions (PdCl2/O2/Cu(OAc)2).

Intramolecular aldol condensation of a triketone, followed by dehydration, to form a fused bicyclic enone (Albaflavenone). The reactant structure as drawn in the screenshot, specifically the right bridgehead, shows two acetyl groups attached to a tertiary carbon which violates carbon valency. The provided reactant SMILES also represents a chemically impossible structure (5-valent carbon). The corrected reactant SMILES places the third acetyl group on an adjacent bridge carbon to represent a chemically valid triketone structure consistent with the overall visual intent and stereochemistry shown in the drawing, while resolving the valency issue.

Double bond hydrogenation (reduction of two C=C bonds). Note: The product structure drawn in the screenshot (fully saturated from two double bonds) does not match the standard chemical structure for Albaflavenone (which typically retains one double bond in the 6-membered ring). The SMILES provided here correspond to the *drawn* product structure.
